description.narrative: Darfur Community and Peace Stability Fund (DCPSF) is a Multi Partners Trust Fund supporting Peace and Stability in Darfur to restore Trust and Confidence and agreeing on a common and/or collaborative approach on how to address root causes of conflict.

participating-org.narrative: MPTFO - Darfur Community Peace and Stability Fund

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
% of community members sampled stating that trust & confidence is restored
· Outputs Indicators:

comment.narrative: Multi-donor pooled fund contributes to community level peacebuilding in Darfur.

Output 1 • Number CBRMs functioning: 133 • community members with access to CBRMs: 69% • community members stating satisfaction with CBRMs: 74% • number of cases submitted to CBRMs successfully addressed: 80% • community members stated a decrease in communal conflicts because of the presence of CBRMs: 65% • % of CBRMs with active participation of vulnerable groups in the decision-making process of the CBRM: 45% • % of CBRM members who are female: 32% • (%) of CBRM members who are youth (15-35 yrs): 37% Output 2 • Number of new/re-established markets that enable diverse communities to interact/cooperate: 24 • Number of community based management mechanisms for natural resource (water, pasture, forest reserves, migration routes, minerals, etc.): 67 • Number of migratory routes demarcated / cleared /rehabilitated through communal consensus: 13 (325 km of migratory routes demarcated) • Number of areas of restoration of communal pasture/fodder/communal forests: 21 • % of community members stated an increase in the economic interventions between diverse communities: 59% • % of community members confirmed communal consensus around restoration of migratory routes/pasture/fodder/communal forests: 58% • % of community members stated an increase in the number of interactions between diverse communities through basic services: 58%. Output 4 • No. of civil society organizations that develop capacity to prioritize, plan, design and implement projects leading to equitable and sustainable growth: 92 • No. of civil society organizations implementing and practicing peacebuilding activities: 50 • No. of collective interactions of conflict resolution mechanisms with state and regional Fora and Agendas: 31

Output 1 • Number CBRMs functioning: 135 • community members with access to CBRMs: 79% • community members stating satisfaction with CBRMs: 71% • number of cases submitted to CBRMs successfully addressed: 83% • community members stated a decrease in communal conflicts because of the presence of CBRMs: 64% • % of CBRMs with active participation of vulnerable groups in the decision-making process of the CBRM: 46% • % of CBRM members who are female: 32% • (%) of CBRM members who are youth (15-35 yrs): 40% Output 2 • Number of new/re-established markets that enable diverse communities to interact/cooperate: 20 • Number of community based management mechanisms for natural resource (water, pasture, forest reserves, migration routes, minerals, etc.): 34 • Number of migratory routes demarcated / cleared /rehabilitated through communal consensus: 8 (140 km of migratory routes demarcated) • Number of areas of restoration of communal pasture/fodder/communal forests: 9 • % of community members stated an increase in the economic interventions between diverse communities: 59% • % of community members confirmed communal consensus around restoration of migratory routes/pasture/fodder/communal forests: 66% • % of community members stated an increase in the number of interactions between diverse communities through basic services: 54%. Output 4 • No. of civil society organizations that develop capacity to prioritize, plan, design and implement projects leading to equitable and sustainable growth: 79 • No. of civil society organizations implementing and practicing peace building activities: 44 • No. of collective interactions of conflict resolution mechanisms with state and regional Fora and Agendas: 29

• Empower women and female youth to meaningfully participate in leadership roles (At least 40% women in key leadership positions in CBRMs and other community initiatives). • Create inclusive decision-making spaces and address protection risks (At least 60% of CBRMs are addressing protection related issues. • Increased learning and scale up of promising practices for gender equal actions (At least 5 learning events held for women and community to educate on gender equality).

• Five training sessions for groups of women, Community Based Resolution Mechanisms (CBRMs) members, government officials and religious leaders on issues of leadership and public speaking; gender in conflict situations; Protection against Sexual Exploitation and Abuse (PSEA); Gender-Based Violence (GBV); and available referral systems. At least 105 women and 24 men from CBRMs and VSLAs groups from both East and South Darfur benefited from these training sessions by December 2020. They went on to encourage women in their groups to speak up in community gatherings or ensure they were actively participating in peacebuilding activities. • Some training around the management of community conflicts included CBRM leaders - who are almost always male - and emphasized the importance of equal representation of women and men in CBRMs. Although early days, there is a slight shift in the perception of women’s participation, with leaders giving female members in CBRMs opportunities to speak in the meetings. It is hoped that by the end of the project, more women will be actively speaking up and taking on leadership roles in the community groups. • Furthermore, a mini baseline project survey was completed in November 2020, exploring the representation and participation in Community Based Resolution Mechanisms in East and South Darfur. In this regard, the survey found that female representation was only 28 percent with only 8 percent of leadership positions held by women. From a sample of 67 groups in both states including 14 CBRMs, 13 Women groups, 14 Youth groups, 13 VSLAs and 13 VDCs, it was found most CBRM members (both men and women) believed the role of women in the groups was to solve women’s issues only. Many also believed that since domestic violence against women was commonplace in their communities, it was not seen as violence against women. The project aims to use radio and drama presentations to change mindsets among the communities on the role of women in peacebuilding and community development.

• Empower women and female youth to meaningfully participate in leadership roles (At least 40% women in key leadership positions in CBRMs and other community initiatives). • Create inclusive decision-making spaces and address protection risks (At least 60% of CBRMs are addressing protection related issues. • Increased learning and scale up of promising practices for gender equal actions (At least 5 learning events held for women and community to educate on gender equality).
